The '1995 Atlanta Braves season' was the 125th season in the history of the
franchise and 30th season in the city of Atlanta. The team finished the strike-
shortened season with a record of 90â54, the best in the National League, en
route to winning the World Series. For the sixth straight season, the team was
managed by Bobby Cox.

The Braves started the season in mediocre fashion, posting a 20â17 record up to
June 4, putting them in third place behind the Philadelphia Phillies and the
Montreal Expos. The team went on to win twenty of the last twenty-five games
before the All-Star Break to put themselves in first place by four and a half
games. In the second half of the season, the Braves pulled away from the rest of
the division by going 11â7 over the rest of July and 19â10 in August. The team
went on to win the division by twenty-one games. The Braves' 90â54 record was
second only to the American League's Cleveland Indians, who went 100â44 on the
season. The National League East title was the first of 11 consecutive NL East
titles and the fourth of 14 consecutive division titles for the Braves (The
Braves won the NL West from 1991â93).

In the postseason, the Braves beat the Colorado Rockies in the NL Division
Series three games to one, then swept the Cincinnati Reds four games to zero to
win the NL Championship Series. In the World Series, the Braves beat the
Cleveland Indians four games to two, bringing the first (and currently only)
World Championship to the city of Atlanta.

Opening Day starter Greg Maddux led the National League in wins (19) and earned
run average (1.63) to secure his fourth consecutive Cy Young
Award. Marquis Grissom won a Gold Glove for center
field, and Greg Maddux won his sixth (of thirteen) consecutive Gold
Gloves.
categories: 1995 Major League Baseball season|Atlanta Braves season
